awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Development of pneumatic memory elements for controlling soft robots with air
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a robotic control that uses air. Rather than controlling robotic systems with microcontrollers and motors, the proposed technology controls commercial robotic platforms with air using minimal electronics. The control approach has not been used in a commercial robotic product to date but may decrease the manufacturing and assembly costs of commercial robotic systems while maintaining or expanding the capabilities of robots.  Initially, the pneumatic components will be used to control a robotic toy as a commercially-viable stepping-stone for powering and controlling commercial robotic systems with pneumatic circuits.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of pneumatic memory elements to control the movement of robots with air.  The robots move by pumping air through channels and embedded air-powered valves. Traditional robots require a motor to control every actuated joint while the proposed technology only requires one pressure source, such as a pump, to control multiple movements.  Recently published results demonstrate the use of air-powered circuits inspired by neural circuits found in animals, called central pattern generators, to control the rhythmic motions of a walking robot without using electronics. The robot was equipped with valves acting as inverters that cause a high-pressure state to spread throughout an air-powered circuit. The robot also was equipped with simple pressure-activated mechanical sensors to change the movement of the robotic appendages. The goal is to transfer this soft robotic technology into a commercially viable product.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our involvement in the NSF I-Corps Teams Program has been instrumental in offering our team invaluable mentorship as we explored the commercial potential of our soft robotics technology.

Introduction:

Our mission is to inspire curiosity, foster creativity, and cultivate critical thinking skills among students by utilizing cutting-edge technology from the field of soft robotics. We are dedicated to transforming STEM education by utilizing our innovative inflatable soft robotic toys. Our toys combine the comfort of a stuffed animal with the STEM educational component of robotics. With our toys, kids stay engaged by building and playing with bioinspired soft robots that are hands-on and user-friendly.

Accomplishments:

Customer Discovery- We conducted an extensive series of over 200 customer interviews, providing invaluable insights into various market segments.

Market Validation- We received positive feedback from potential customers, affirming a strong demand for our soft robotic toys.

Business Model Canvas- We developed and refined our business model canvas, pinpointing key partners, revenue streams, and distribution channels crucial for our venture's success.

Prototype Development- We Iterated on our soft robotics prototypes, guided by user experience feedback gathered during customer interviews.

Commercialization Roadmap- We created a comprehensive commercialization roadmap that outlines key milestones, timelines, and resource requirements for the successful launch of our soft robotics toys.

Key Findings:

Market Need- We analyzed competing products and technologies on the market enabling us to identify opportunities for differentiation and establish a competitive advantage. Our research revealed a demand for flexible and soft robotic solutions in the toy industry, addressing limitations of traditional rigid robotic toys on the market. Kids prefer soft robotic companions that they can treat like pets, while parents appreciate the educational and collaborative aspects of the toys. By identifying various pain points and preferences, we were able to tailor our designs to specific customer segments.

Market Entry Strategy-We conducted pilot studies to confirm the best entry points into our target markets. For instance, we introduced different soft robotic toys into a school in the LA unified school district which contained a diverse group of students from different socioeconomic classes. In addition, we formed strategic partners in the toy industry that will be crucial in our product development phase.

Future Steps:

Funding Pursuit- Our next steps involve pursuing non-dilutive funding opportunities, such as PFI/SBIR/STTR grants, to further support our research and product development efforts.

Partner Engagement- We plan to build strategic partnerships with industry leaders, research institutions, and investors that will be crucial for accelerating our product development.

Market Expansion- We will then explore additional verticals and applications for our soft robotics technology. The same methods used to control soft robotic toys can be used to control other robotic platforms.

Conclusion:

Through our project, we've introduced soft robotic toys into schools, preparing students for the challenges of tomorrow's world. These efforts aim to inspire interest in STEM fields and provide valuable hands-on learning experiences. The NSF I-Corps Teams Program has played a pivotal role by equipping us with the necessary tools and insights to propel our innovative soft robotics technology into a viable business venture. Our soft robotic toys have broader applications, and through collaboration with research labs and students, we aim to bridge the gap between academia and industry by facilitating the commercialization of soft robotic technologies. We are enthusiastic about continuing this journey and bringing our transformative technology to market, driving innovation and making a significant impact on the field of soft robotics.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Michael T Tolley
